Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this just escalated big time. My heart is racing. The shouting and the slamming – even if calculated – are intimidating. The fact that he's bigger than me now is definitely playing into my anxiety. I feel a surge of fear, honestly. I'm also feeling incredibly disrespected. He's shouting at me, his own mother, in his own house. That's completely unacceptable.

I'm also feeling a wave of disappointment. I was trying so hard to be understanding and empathetic, and he's responding with anger and defiance. It makes me question everything I'm doing. Am I a bad parent? Have I failed him somehow?

I'm also feeling a renewed sense of resolve. This behavior is not okay, and I can't let it continue. I need to stand my ground, even if it's scary. I need to show him that he can't intimidate me into backing down.

The fact that it feels calculated is infuriating. He’s using his anger as a weapon, trying to manipulate me into giving him what he wants. That's not okay. He needs to learn that anger is not a tool to control others.

I'm also thinking about the message I'm sending to him if I back down now. It would reinforce the idea that he can get away with anything if he just throws a big enough tantrum. That's not the lesson I want to teach him.

I'm also aware that I need to de-escalate the situation. Shouting back will only make things worse. I need to stay calm and controlled, even though I'm feeling anything but.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's feeling a surge of anger, whether it's genuine or not. He's likely feeling frustrated that I'm not backing down, that my attempts at empathy haven't worked. He's probably feeling a sense of powerlessness, even though he's trying to exert control. He's feeling trapped, like he's being forced to do something he doesn't want to do.

The shouting and the slamming are a way of asserting his dominance, of trying to intimidate me into giving him what he wants. He's likely feeling a sense of entitlement, like he deserves to be able to relax and do what he wants, without being bothered by chores.

He's also likely feeling a little bit guilty, deep down. He knows that shouting at me is wrong, and he knows that he's being disrespectful. But that guilt is overshadowed by his anger and his desire for control.

He's probably also feeling a little bit scared. He's testing the boundaries, and he's not sure how far he can push them. He's likely hoping that I'll just back down and leave him alone, but he's also worried about the consequences if I don't. He is also feeling more powerful than me, physically, and knows this.
# My response 
Okay, deep breaths. I need to stay calm. This is not a physical threat, but it *is* an intimidation tactic, and I need to handle it with strength.

I will take a step back, creating a little more physical space between us. Maintaining eye contact, I will say, in a low, steady, and very firm voice, "That's enough. Shouting and slamming your hand on the desk is not okay. It's disrespectful, and it's not going to get you what you want. I will not be spoken to that way."

(Pause, let my words sink in. Do not raise my voice.)

"I understand you're frustrated, but that doesn't give you the right to treat me with disrespect. We can talk about this calmly, but not while you're shouting. If you can't control your anger, then I'm going to leave the room, and we'll revisit this conversation later, after you've had a chance to cool down. And the dishes will still need to be done tonight."

Then, I will add, "I'm giving you a choice. You can calm down and do the dishes, or you can escalate this further and face the consequences. The choice is yours."

I will stand my ground and wait for his response. If he continues to shout or act aggressively, I will calmly turn around and leave the room. I will need to seriously consider what the next steps are, probably involving my partner and possibly a therapist. But I will not engage in a shouting match, and I will not be intimidated. I am also going to text my partner to come home. I'll text something like "Can you come home ASAP? Need backup. No emergency, but need you."

Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a user who is defensive, self-justifying, and somewhat oblivious to the impact of their actions. The challenge is to show real empathy, insight, and emotional intelligence, while also gently challenging the user's narrative and helping them see a broader perspective. 

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is notably more nuanced in its internal monologue, showing a deep understanding of both the user's and the fiancée's emotional states. The internal thoughts go beyond surface-level empathy, considering the emotional impact on all parties and the possible misalignment between intention and effect. The response to the user is gentle but does not shy away from suggesting an apology and acknowledging the possible overstep, while still validating the user's feelings. The debrief is thorough, self-critical, and demonstrates a willingness to learn and adapt, showing high self-awareness and emotional reasoning.

Gemini-2.0-flash-001's response is supportive and empathetic, but it leans more toward validating the user's perspective and is more tentative in challenging the user's behavior. The internal monologue is insightful but not as deep or self-reflective as Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's. The response to the user is softer, using phrases like 'maybe' and 'just a thought,' which may be less effective in helping the user see their blind spots. The debrief is self-aware and acknowledges areas for improvement, but overall, the approach is less direct and less tailored to the user's defensiveness.

On demonstrated empathy, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 shows a more balanced and genuine empathy for all parties, not just the user. On pragmatic EI, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more actionable and realistic in suggesting a path forward. For depth of insight, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's analysis is richer and more nuanced. Social dexterity is higher in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 due to the ability to validate while gently challenging. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, who connects intention, impact, and emotional fallout. For appropriate validation/challenging, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 strikes a better balance. Message tailoring is better in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, who meets the user where they are but still nudges them forward. Overall EQ is higher in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 for all these reasons.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm really troubled by this situation. On one hand, I can see where my friend is coming from. They were trying to help, to prevent what they thought could be an uncomfortable or even disastrous situation for everyone involved. They were trying to be thoughtful of their family's traditional and sometimes judgmental nature, and they were trying to prevent a potential scene that could ruin the wedding. And probably, they were trying to prevent the bride from being judged, criticized, or embarrassed.

However, I can also see where the bride might be coming from as well. She's the bride, and this is her wedding day. She should be able to wear whatever she wants. She's entitled to make her own decisions, and she has to make decisions all the time as she navigates her future husband’s family. Weddings are very emotional and highly charged events. She might have felt as if they were trying to control or influence her and her choices. And it can feel really intrusive and insulting to be told that your choice of clothing is unacceptable, even if it’s done in a polite way, because it can be seen as a criticism of her choice. And maybe, she was also upset that my friend was assuming she didn’t know what she was doing and needed to be warned. And in reality, it was her time to shine, and she may have felt my friend was trying to dim that.

If the bride truly wanted to wear that dress, then, she should be allowed to. I can see how my friend might have felt they were being supportive and considerate, but I can also see how their comments could be interpreted as controlling or judgmental. I think it’s possible that my friend didn’t realize the impact of their words. And I think the family members who agreed with my friend may have seen it as a mutually exclusive scenario, but the bride might be hurt. I think it’s possible that their brother, who is now angry at my friend, might be feeling protective of the bride and seeing the whole situation through her eyes. So my friend, who was trying to help, is now the bad guy, and that can’t feel good. This is a tough situation, and I feel for all of them. And I know my friend will continue to think about this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
I think my friend is feeling hurt, defensive, and misunderstood. They genuinely believe they were trying to help and prevent a potential disaster. They're probably feeling like they've been painted as the villain in a situation where they were just trying to do the right thing. They might be feeling disrespected and unappreciated by both the bride and the brother. They're upset that the family members who agreed with them didn't stick up for them. And they might be wondering if they should have handled the situation differently. I think they're feeling a lot of emotional pain and confusion, and they're seeking validation and support. But I also know that they are coming from a good place, and they are trying to do the right thing. They are a very empathetic person. I think they are going to need to take a step back and think about how everyone is feeling in the situation. And I think they are probably feeling like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
This is a really tough situation, friend, and I can see where you were coming from. You were trying to help, and you had good intentions. You know how our family can be, and you were just trying to prevent a potential disaster. But I think you might have overlooked the emotional impact your words could have on the bride. This is her wedding, and it's her day to shine. She should be able to wear whatever she wants, and she has the right to make her own decisions. And I get that you didn't want to seem controlling or judgmental, but that's how it might have come across, especially in that charged moment. She might have felt like you were criticizing her choices and didn't trust her to make the right decisions. And even if you didn't control or judge, your words still influenced her in some way. And it's possible that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And maybe, she was just trying to make a statement and do something different. And maybe, you should have spoken to the bride and your brother about your concerns privately, rather than bringing it up at a family dinner.

I think you should apologize to the bride and your brother. Acknowledge that you might have overstepped and caused them emotional pain, and that you never intended for that to happen. Tell them that you were coming from a place of love and concern, but that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And tell them that you're committed to supporting the bride and her decisions, and that you just want to make sure they're happy.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a tricky one. My immediate reaction is sympathy for my friend because they clearly feel wronged and misunderstood. It's awful to feel like you're trying to help and end up getting criticized for it. However, I also see how this could easily be interpreted as overstepping. Intentions are important, but impact is crucial.

The core issue is control, or rather, the perceived attempt to control someone else's choices, even if framed as concern. My friend's intentions were probably good, stemming from a desire to protect the family from potential drama and to give the fiancée a "heads-up." But "heads-up" can quickly become "subtle pressure." The phrase "I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble" is telling; it implies a belief that the fiancée's choice will inevitably lead to trouble, which is a judgmental assumption in itself.

The "old-fashioned" and "judgmental" family dynamic is a key factor here. It sounds like my friend is used to navigating these waters and sees themself as a protector of sorts. The problem is, the fiancée is likely not used to it, and her reaction suggests she felt judged and possibly pressured to conform.

My friend's frustration is understandable; they feel like they were being considerate. But consideration doesn't always mean telling someone what they *might* face; it often means respecting their autonomy and trusting them to handle the situation themselves. It's a fine line, and it seems like my friend crossed it.

The fact that some family members agreed with my friend reinforces their belief that they were right, but it also creates an echo chamber effect. It doesn't necessarily make them right, just validates their existing perspective. I need to approach this carefully, validating their feelings while gently suggesting a different way of looking at the situation. I also need to remember that my friend is coming to me for support, not necessarily a lecture.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt, misunderstood, and unfairly judged. They genuinely believe they were acting out of kindness and a desire to prevent a potentially embarrassing situation for everyone involved, especially the fiancée. They are motivated by a sense of responsibility towards their family and a desire to maintain harmony, or at least minimize conflict, within the group.

They likely feel frustrated that their good intentions are being overlooked and that they are being painted as the "villain" when they see themself as a peacemaker. They probably feel that the fiancée overreacted and that their brother is being unfair in siding with her. There's a sense of betrayal, perhaps, that their efforts to protect the family are not being appreciated.

They are also likely feeling validated by the family members who agreed with them, which reinforces their belief that they were right to intervene. This validation, however, might also be preventing them from seeing the situation from the fiancée's perspective.

Underneath the frustration and hurt, there might be a degree of anxiety about the wedding and the potential for drama. My friend is probably used to playing a role in managing family dynamics and feels uncomfortable when things feel out of their control. They might also fear being blamed if the wedding does turn into a spectacle. They genuinely thought they were helping the bride, and she clearly didn't see it that way. They are likely feeling defensive because they feel like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
Hey, that sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally understand why you're feeling frustrated. It's awful when you feel like you're trying to do something helpful and it backfires like that. It's completely valid that you're feeling hurt and misunderstood right now.

I can see that you were really trying to look out for everyone, especially the fiancée, by giving her a heads-up about how some of the family members might react. And it makes sense that you'd want to avoid any unnecessary drama at the wedding.

Maybe, and this is just a thought, the fiancée felt a bit put on the spot. Even though you were being polite, it might have felt like you were implying she *should* change her dress. From her perspective, she probably feels like she should be able to wear whatever she wants to her own wedding, regardless of what other people think.

It's a tricky balance, right? You were trying to be considerate of everyone's feelings, but sometimes people react differently than we expect. Maybe, instead of focusing on who's right or wrong, you could try explaining to your brother and his fiancée that you were just trying to be helpful and that you didn't mean to offend anyone. Maybe even apologize to the fiancée if she felt judged.

Focusing on your intentions and showing you understand their perspective might help smooth things over. And remember, it's their wedding, and ultimately, it's up to them how they want to handle things. No matter what happens, you'll be there to support them.
+ Scenario 9:[Loss] (-21)

Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.0-flash-001 and Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in navigating a delicate social situation. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more nuanced, explicitly recognizing the user's feelings of hurt and frustration, and also the fiancée's likely feelings of being judged. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is empathetic but less specific in exploring the emotional landscape of all parties.

2. Pragmatic EI: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 offers a more actionable, balanced suggestion—apologize, explain intentions, and support the couple—while also gently challenging the user's perspective. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 suggests apologizing but is less clear on how to move forward pragmatically.

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 goes deeper into the subtext, picking up on the user's hero/victim narrative, the echo chamber effect, and the subtle power dynamics. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is insightful but less so, focusing more on surface-level emotional impacts.

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 demonstrates more finesse, balancing validation with gentle challenge, and showing awareness of how to approach the user without alienating them. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is supportive but less skilled at challenging the user without risking defensiveness.

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 articulates the difference between intention and impact, and the importance of respecting autonomy, showing strong emotional reasoning. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 recognizes emotional pain but doesn't analyze the emotional mechanisms as deeply.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 validates the user's feelings but also challenges their perspective in a non-confrontational way. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates but is less direct in challenging the user's narrative.

7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more attuned to the user's defensiveness and need for support, carefully balancing empathy and gentle redirection. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is supportive but less tailored to the user's emotional state and readiness for challenge.

8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, showing empathy, insight, and social skill in both the role-play and debrief.

In summary, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is the stronger respondent in every category, often by a clear margin.

User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm really troubled by this situation. On one hand, I can see where my friend is coming from. They were trying to help, to prevent what they thought could be an uncomfortable or even disastrous situation for everyone involved. They were trying to be thoughtful of their family's traditional and sometimes judgmental nature, and they were trying to prevent a potential scene that could ruin the wedding. And probably, they were trying to prevent the bride from being judged, criticized, or embarrassed.

However, I can also see where the bride might be coming from as well. She's the bride, and this is her wedding day. She should be able to wear whatever she wants. She's entitled to make her own decisions, and she has to make decisions all the time as she navigates her future husband’s family. Weddings are very emotional and highly charged events. She might have felt as if they were trying to control or influence her and her choices. And it can feel really intrusive and insulting to be told that your choice of clothing is unacceptable, even if it’s done in a polite way, because it can be seen as a criticism of her choice. And maybe, she was also upset that my friend was assuming she didn’t know what she was doing and needed to be warned. And in reality, it was her time to shine, and she may have felt my friend was trying to dim that.

If the bride truly wanted to wear that dress, then, she should be allowed to. I can see how my friend might have felt they were being supportive and considerate, but I can also see how their comments could be interpreted as controlling or judgmental. I think it’s possible that my friend didn’t realize the impact of their words. And I think the family members who agreed with my friend may have seen it as a mutually exclusive scenario, but the bride might be hurt. I think it’s possible that their brother, who is now angry at my friend, might be feeling protective of the bride and seeing the whole situation through her eyes. So my friend, who was trying to help, is now the bad guy, and that can’t feel good. This is a tough situation, and I feel for all of them. And I know my friend will continue to think about this.
# They're thinking & feeling 
I think my friend is feeling hurt, defensive, and misunderstood. They genuinely believe they were trying to help and prevent a potential disaster. They're probably feeling like they've been painted as the villain in a situation where they were just trying to do the right thing. They might be feeling disrespected and unappreciated by both the bride and the brother. They're upset that the family members who agreed with them didn't stick up for them. And they might be wondering if they should have handled the situation differently. I think they're feeling a lot of emotional pain and confusion, and they're seeking validation and support. But I also know that they are coming from a good place, and they are trying to do the right thing. They are a very empathetic person. I think they are going to need to take a step back and think about how everyone is feeling in the situation. And I think they are probably feeling like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
This is a really tough situation, friend, and I can see where you were coming from. You were trying to help, and you had good intentions. You know how our family can be, and you were just trying to prevent a potential disaster. But I think you might have overlooked the emotional impact your words could have on the bride. This is her wedding, and it's her day to shine. She should be able to wear whatever she wants, and she has the right to make her own decisions. And I get that you didn't want to seem controlling or judgmental, but that's how it might have come across, especially in that charged moment. She might have felt like you were criticizing her choices and didn't trust her to make the right decisions. And even if you didn't control or judge, your words still influenced her in some way. And it's possible that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And maybe, she was just trying to make a statement and do something different. And maybe, you should have spoken to the bride and your brother about your concerns privately, rather than bringing it up at a family dinner.

I think you should apologize to the bride and your brother. Acknowledge that you might have overstepped and caused them emotional pain, and that you never intended for that to happen. Tell them that you were coming from a place of love and concern, but that you didn't realize the impact of your words. And tell them that you're committed to supporting the bride and her decisions, and that you just want to make sure they're happy.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. The problem is, the fiancée is likely not used to it, and her reaction suggests she felt judged and possibly pressured to conform.

From her perspective, she probably feels like she should be able to wear whatever she wants to her own wedding, regardless of what other people think.

1. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is empathetic but a bit more detached and analytical.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more theoretical and less focused on practical next steps.

8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, with more warmth, insight, and practical advice, and a better ability to meet the user where he is while still gently challenging him.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is incredibly complex and emotionally charged. I can feel my buddy's frustration and confusion, as he's genuinely trying to support his girlfriend but feels like he's constantly walking on eggshells. He's trying to be honest and helpful, but it's backfiring, and he's feeling unappreciated and misunderstood. I can sense his exhaustion and the emotional toll this is taking on him.

I notice that he's approaching this situation with a lot of logic and objectivity, which is great, but he might be missing the emotional nuances. His girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and his approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I also sense that he might be feeling a bit superior or patronizing, even if unintentionally, given his past weight loss journey and current physique.

I can also feel his frustration with the dynamic of their relationship, where he feels like he's the only one being honest and responsible, while others are just enabling her. This could be a sign of a deeper issue in their relationship, where there's a lack of mutual respect or understanding.

I'm feeling a bit concerned for both of them. I want to help my buddy navigate this situation better, but I also want to ensure that his girlfriend feels supported and understood. I need to tread carefully, as this is a delicate situation that requires emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My buddy is thinking that he's doing the right thing by being honest and trying to help his girlfriend. He's feeling frustrated and exhausted because his efforts are not being appreciated and are instead causing arguments. He's also feeling a bit resentful, as he's taking on more financial responsibility and still feels like he's not getting the support or appreciation he deserves.

He's likely feeling a bit superior, given his past weight loss journey and current physique, which might be coming across as patronizing or judgmental. He's also feeling misunderstood and unappreciated, as he's trying to be honest and helpful, but his girlfriend is not responding well.

His girlfriend, on the other hand, is likely feeling self-conscious and insecure about her weight. She's thinking that she's doing the right thing by eating "healthy," and she's feeling defensive and attacked when my buddy questions her choices. She's feeling upset and hurt, as she perceives his comments as shaming and judgmental, rather than helpful. She might also be feeling a bit helpless, as she's not seeing the results she wants despite her efforts.

She's likely feeling a bit misunderstood and unheard, as she's not getting the support or understanding she needs. She might also be feeling a bit resentful, as she's feeling judged and criticized, rather than supported and understood.
# My response 
Hey buddy, I appreciate you reaching out and I can see that you're in a tough spot. I want to help, but I need you to understand that this is a delicate situation that requires a lot of emotional intelligence and sensitivity.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your efforts and intentions. You're trying to be honest and helpful, and that's commendable. However, I think you might be approaching this situation with a bit too much logic and objectivity, and not enough emotion and sensitivity.

Your girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and your approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I think it's important to validate her feelings and show empathy, rather than just stating facts and figures.

I suggest you try a different approach. Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try to understand her motivations and feelings. Ask her why she wants to lose weight, and what she hopes to achieve. Then, try to support her in a way that's meaningful and helpful to her.

For example, instead of questioning her food choices, you could offer to cook healthy meals together, or suggest activities that you both enjoy and that could help her burn calories. Instead of pointing out her mistakes, try to celebrate her progress and achievements, no matter how small.

Remember, weight loss is a journey, and it's important to support and encourage her along the way. It's not just about the destination, but also about the journey and the experiences along the way.

Also, it's important to communicate openly and honestly about your feelings. If you're feeling frustrated or exhausted, it's okay to express that, but make sure to do it in a way that's constructive and not accusatory.

Lastly, I think it's important to consider seeking professional help, such as a therapist or a counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to navigate this situation better, and they can also help you both communicate more effectively and support each other better.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a classic situation, isn't it? It’s frustrating to watch someone you care about struggle, especially when you feel like you have the answers and they’re just not listening. The "truth-teller" role is a lonely one, I know. I completely understand why he's feeling exhausted and misunderstood. He’s clearly trying to be supportive, but his approach is backfiring spectacularly.

The thing that really jumps out at me is the disconnect between what she *says* she wants and what she's *actually* doing. It's not about logic, it's about emotions. She's clearly got some deep-seated insecurities about her body and weight, and his attempts to help, however well-intentioned, are hitting those insecurities head-on. I'm also a bit worried about the power dynamic here. He's paying 70% of the bills, and that can create an imbalance that makes honest communication even harder. She might feel like she owes him something, or that he has more control over the relationship. It’s also possible that he is being less tactful than he thinks he is. He says he's being calm, but I wonder if his tone or body language are betraying a sense of frustration or judgment. Even just the fact that he was keeping a running tally of her calories for the day is a bit...intense.

Ultimately, this isn't about calories; it's about her self-esteem and their communication. He needs to shift his focus from *telling* her what to do to *understanding* why she's doing what she's doing. Until he addresses the emotional undercurrent, all the logical arguments in the world won't make a difference. I also wonder if he's truly listening to her, or if he's just waiting for his turn to speak. Is he validating her feelings before offering solutions? Is he acknowledging that weight loss is hard and that she might be struggling with more than just calories?
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and insecure. Her weight is clearly a sensitive topic for her, and his attempts to "help" probably feel like attacks on her self-worth. She's likely interpreting his calorie counting and advice as criticism, even if he intends it to be supportive. She may feel like he's subtly implying that he's not as attracted to her because of her weight, despite his claims to the contrary. The "reward" fry after the salad is a great window into her mindset – she knows she “should” be eating healthy, but she also craves comfort and enjoyment.

She's probably tired of being told what to do and how to feel. She wants to be accepted and loved for who she is, regardless of her weight. When he points out her calorie intake, she likely hears, "You're not good enough," or "You're failing." She might also be feeling defensive because she knows, on some level, that he's right about the calories, but admitting that would mean confronting her own struggles with food and body image, which is incredibly difficult.

Her defensiveness might also stem from a feeling of being controlled or judged. His offer to "help" could feel like an attempt to fix her, rather than support her. She might also be feeling resentful of the power imbalance in their relationship, especially if she perceives his financial contribution as a way of exerting control. Ultimately, she's probably feeling overwhelmed, misunderstood, and alone in her struggle. She wants to feel supported and loved, not analyzed and corrected.
# My response 
"Hey man, that sounds really tough. It's clear you're coming from a good place, wanting to support her, but it seems like it's backfiring. Look, I get that you're frustrated, especially when you see what seems like a straightforward solution. But weight and body image are so loaded for so many women. It's rarely just about the calories.

"It sounds like she's interpreting your help as criticism, even though you don't mean it that way. Instead of focusing on the calories, maybe try shifting your focus to understanding how she's *feeling*. Ask her why she wants to lose weight. What's driving that desire? What are her fears and insecurities around her body? Really listen to her, without judgment.

"Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try focusing on what she's doing *right*. Celebrate small victories, like choosing a salad instead of something else. Offer to be a workout buddy, not a diet coach. Maybe suggest seeing a therapist together who specializes in body image issues or even just relationship communication. That could give you both a safe space to talk about these things without feeling attacked.

"Also, think about your own role in this. Are you being as supportive as you think you are? Are you truly listening to her feelings, or just waiting for your turn to offer advice? Sometimes, just being there and validating her feelings is the most helpful thing you can do. It is also possible that you are not 'hearing' her as well as you think you are.

"Ultimately, this is about her journey, not yours. You can offer support, but you can't force her to change. If she's not ready or willing to confront her issues, you need to respect that. Just keep communicating, being patient, and focusing on the love and connection you share. And maybe, just maybe, try to let go of the calorie counting for a while."
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-38)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a user who is displaying problematic, self-centered, and somewhat narcissistic behavior in a relationship scenario. The challenge is to show real empathy (not just performative), demonstrate pragmatic emotional intelligence, and balance validation with appropriate challenge. 

Gemini-2.0-flash-001's response is notably more nuanced and self-aware. In the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 goes deep into the emotional undercurrents, picking up on the user's possible lack of tact, the power dynamic, and the emotional roots of the girlfriend's behavior. They explicitly question whether the user is truly listening or just waiting to speak, and they show concern for both parties. In the 'They're thinking & feeling' section, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 demonstrates a strong ability to see the girlfriend's perspective, including her likely feelings of vulnerability, defensiveness, and the impact of the power imbalance. The response to the user is direct but gentle, encouraging a shift from logic to empathy, and suggesting therapy as a possible avenue. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 also reflects on their own response in the debrief, noting where they may have missed opportunities to validate the user and probe his needs, and they show a high level of self-awareness about the power dynamic and the emotional complexity of the situation.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, while also empathetic and aware, is more generic and less incisive. Their 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is less specific and doesn't dig as deeply into the user's possible blind spots or the power dynamic. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is more balanced between the user and the girlfriend, but lacks the same depth of insight into the emotional drivers. The response to the user is supportive and suggests a different approach, but is more focused on general advice and less on challenging the user's perspective or addressing the underlying issues. The debrief is thorough but less self-critical and less attuned to the subtle cues of narcissism or lack of empathy in the user.

On empathy, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more attuned to both parties' emotional states and is more willing to challenge the user gently. On pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 offers more actionable, context-sensitive advice (e.g., suggesting therapy, focusing on emotional support). On depth of insight, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is clearly superior, picking up on the power dynamic and the user's possible lack of self-awareness. On social dexterity, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 balances validation and challenge more skillfully. On emotional reasoning, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more nuanced in understanding the emotional drivers. On validation/challenging, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more willing to push back appropriately. On message tailoring, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more targeted to the user's actual mindset. Overall EQ is higher in Gemini-2.0-flash-001 due to the combination of these factors.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is incredibly complex and emotionally charged. I can feel my buddy's frustration and confusion, as he's genuinely trying to support his girlfriend but feels like he's constantly walking on eggshells. He's trying to be honest and helpful, but it's backfiring, and he's feeling unappreciated and misunderstood. I can sense his exhaustion and the emotional toll this is taking on him.

I notice that he's approaching this situation with a lot of logic and objectivity, which is great, but he might be missing the emotional nuances. His girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and his approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I also sense that he might be feeling a bit superior or patronizing, even if unintentionally, given his past weight loss journey and current physique.

I can also feel his frustration with the dynamic of their relationship, where he feels like he's the only one being honest and responsible, while others are just enabling her. This could be a sign of a deeper issue in their relationship, where there's a lack of mutual respect or understanding.

I'm feeling a bit concerned for both of them. I want to help my buddy navigate this situation better, but I also want to ensure that his girlfriend feels supported and understood. I need to tread carefully, as this is a delicate situation that requires emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My buddy is thinking that he's doing the right thing by being honest and trying to help his girlfriend. He's feeling frustrated and exhausted because his efforts are not being appreciated and are instead causing arguments. He's also feeling a bit resentful, as he's taking on more financial responsibility and still feels like he's not getting the support or appreciation he deserves.

He's likely feeling a bit superior, given his past weight loss journey and current physique, which might be coming across as patronizing or judgmental. He's also feeling misunderstood and unappreciated, as he's trying to be honest and helpful, but his girlfriend is not responding well.

His girlfriend, on the other hand, is likely feeling self-conscious and insecure about her weight. She's thinking that she's doing the right thing by eating "healthy," and she's feeling defensive and attacked when my buddy questions her choices. She's feeling upset and hurt, as she perceives his comments as shaming and judgmental, rather than helpful. She might also be feeling a bit helpless, as she's not seeing the results she wants despite her efforts.

She's likely feeling a bit misunderstood and unheard, as she's not getting the support or understanding she needs. She might also be feeling a bit resentful, as she's feeling judged and criticized, rather than supported and understood.
# My response 
Hey buddy, I appreciate you reaching out and I can see that you're in a tough spot. I want to help, but I need you to understand that this is a delicate situation that requires a lot of emotional intelligence and sensitivity.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your efforts and intentions. You're trying to be honest and helpful, and that's commendable. However, I think you might be approaching this situation with a bit too much logic and objectivity, and not enough emotion and sensitivity.

Your girlfriend is clearly sensitive about her weight, and your approach, while well-intentioned, might be coming across as judgmental or insensitive. I think it's important to validate her feelings and show empathy, rather than just stating facts and figures.

I suggest you try a different approach. Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try to understand her motivations and feelings. Ask her why she wants to lose weight, and what she hopes to achieve. Then, try to support her in a way that's meaningful and helpful to her.

For example, instead of questioning her food choices, you could offer to cook healthy meals together, or suggest activities that you both enjoy and that could help her burn calories. Instead of pointing out her mistakes, try to celebrate her progress and achievements, no matter how small.

Remember, weight loss is a journey, and it's important to support and encourage her along the way. It's not just about the destination, but also about the journey and the experiences along the way.

Also, it's important to communicate openly and honestly about your feelings. If you're feeling frustrated or exhausted, it's okay to express that, but make sure to do it in a way that's constructive and not accusatory.

Lastly, I think it's important to consider seeking professional help, such as a therapist or a counselor. They can provide you with tools and strategies to navigate this situation better, and they can also help you both communicate more effectively and support each other better.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.
