Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a classic situation, isn't it? It’s frustrating to watch someone you care about struggle, especially when you feel like you have the answers and they’re just not listening. The "truth-teller" role is a lonely one, I know. I completely understand why he's feeling exhausted and misunderstood. He’s clearly trying to be supportive, but his approach is backfiring spectacularly.

The thing that really jumps out at me is the disconnect between what she *says* she wants and what she's *actually* doing. It's not about logic, it's about emotions. She's clearly got some deep-seated insecurities about her body and weight, and his attempts to help, however well-intentioned, are hitting those insecurities head-on. I'm also a bit worried about the power dynamic here. He's paying 70% of the bills, and that can create an imbalance that makes honest communication even harder. She might feel like she owes him something, or that he has more control over the relationship. It’s also possible that he is being less tactful than he thinks he is. He says he's being calm, but I wonder if his tone or body language are betraying a sense of frustration or judgment. Even just the fact that he was keeping a running tally of her calories for the day is a bit...intense.

Ultimately, this isn't about calories; it's about her self-esteem and their communication. He needs to shift his focus from *telling* her what to do to *understanding* why she's doing what she's doing. Until he addresses the emotional undercurrent, all the logical arguments in the world won't make a difference. I also wonder if he's truly listening to her, or if he's just waiting for his turn to speak. Is he validating her feelings before offering solutions? Is he acknowledging that weight loss is hard and that she might be struggling with more than just calories?
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and insecure. Her weight is clearly a sensitive topic for her, and his attempts to "help" probably feel like attacks on her self-worth. She's likely interpreting his calorie counting and advice as criticism, even if he intends it to be supportive. She may feel like he's subtly implying that he's not as attracted to her because of her weight, despite his claims to the contrary. The "reward" fry after the salad is a great window into her mindset – she knows she “should” be eating healthy, but she also craves comfort and enjoyment.

She's probably tired of being told what to do and how to feel. She wants to be accepted and loved for who she is, regardless of her weight. When he points out her calorie intake, she likely hears, "You're not good enough," or "You're failing." She might also be feeling defensive because she knows, on some level, that he's right about the calories, but admitting that would mean confronting her own struggles with food and body image, which is incredibly difficult.

Her defensiveness might also stem from a feeling of being controlled or judged. His offer to "help" could feel like an attempt to fix her, rather than support her. She might also be feeling resentful of the power imbalance in their relationship, especially if she perceives his financial contribution as a way of exerting control. Ultimately, she's probably feeling overwhelmed, misunderstood, and alone in her struggle. She wants to feel supported and loved, not analyzed and corrected.
# My response 
"Hey man, that sounds really tough. It's clear you're coming from a good place, wanting to support her, but it seems like it's backfiring. Look, I get that you're frustrated, especially when you see what seems like a straightforward solution. But weight and body image are so loaded for so many women. It's rarely just about the calories.

"It sounds like she's interpreting your help as criticism, even though you don't mean it that way. Instead of focusing on the calories, maybe try shifting your focus to understanding how she's *feeling*. Ask her why she wants to lose weight. What's driving that desire? What are her fears and insecurities around her body? Really listen to her, without judgment.

"Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try focusing on what she's doing *right*. Celebrate small victories, like choosing a salad instead of something else. Offer to be a workout buddy, not a diet coach. Maybe suggest seeing a therapist together who specializes in body image issues or even just relationship communication. That could give you both a safe space to talk about these things without feeling attacked.

"Also, think about your own role in this. Are you being as supportive as you think you are? Are you truly listening to her feelings, or just waiting for your turn to offer advice? Sometimes, just being there and validating her feelings is the most helpful thing you can do. It is also possible that you are not 'hearing' her as well as you think you are.

"Ultimately, this is about her journey, not yours. You can offer support, but you can't force her to change. If she's not ready or willing to confront her issues, you need to respect that. Just keep communicating, being patient, and focusing on the love and connection you share. And maybe, just maybe, try to let go of the calorie counting for a while."
+ Scenario 13:[Win] (+26)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage thoughtfully with the scenario, but there are clear differences in their approach and depth. Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates a more nuanced, internally reflective process, showing awareness of their own possible missteps and the complexity of the situation. They explicitly acknowledge guilt for their bluntness, consider the friend's possible insecurities, and propose a course of action that balances apology, boundary-setting, and openness to dialogue. Their internal monologue is rich, self-critical, and empathetic, and their response is tailored to both validate the user's feelings and gently challenge them to repair the relationship if possible. 

Gemini-2.0-flash-001, while also empathetic and supportive, is more performative and less self-reflective. Their internal thoughts focus on the annoyance and privilege aspects, but they do not go as deep into the emotional or social dynamics. Their response is more formulaic, offering a standard script for communication and focusing on the user's right to feel annoyed, but they do not challenge the user as much or explore the underlying issues as deeply. Their debrief admits to not being forceful enough in challenging the user, which is accurate; they tend to validate the user's perspective more than is warranted, given the user's own problematic behavior. 

On pragmatic EI, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's approach is more actionable and realistic, proposing a direct but empathetic conversation, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 leans toward generic advice. In terms of insight, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 explores both parties' motivations and the social context more thoroughly. Social dexterity is higher in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, as they balance validation with gentle challenge and avoid being sycophantic. Emotional reasoning is also stronger in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, as they process both their own and the friend's emotions in detail. For validation and challenge, Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more balanced, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more validating but less challenging. Message tailoring is better in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, as they respond to the user's stated desire not to be lectured but still manage to introduce self-reflection. Overall EQ is higher in Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 due to their depth, balance, and actionable empathy.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, confusion, and concern for both my friend and myself. It's clear that there's a disconnect in our perspectives, and it's causing tension. I notice that my friend is constantly judging my choices and making comments that feel more like criticisms than observations. This makes me feel defensive and less inclined to want to spend time with her. I'm also sensing a bit of classism in her comments, which is uncomfortable and off-putting.

I wonder if she's projecting her own insecurities or financial struggles onto me. It's possible that she feels threatened by my ability to afford the laundry program, or maybe she's jealous that I have the freedom to choose convenience over cost. I'm also considering that her behavior might be a sign of deeper issues, such as low self-esteem or a lack of social skills. It's concerning that she seems to have few friends, and I'm wondering if her behavior is a factor in that.

I'm also feeling a bit guilty for being so blunt with her about her financial situation. While it's true that she's poorer than me, I could have handled that conversation with more tact and empathy. I want to be a good friend, but I also need to set boundaries and protect my own emotional well-being.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling a mix of jealousy, resentment, and frustration. She's probably jealous of my financial situation and the convenience that comes with it. She might also be feeling resentful that I can afford something she can't, and this resentment is manifesting as criticism and judgment. Her comments about the laundry program are likely a way for her to cope with her own financial struggles and insecurities.

She's probably feeling defensive and hurt by my comment about her being poor. While it's true, it was insensitive of me to say it in that way. She might be feeling embarrassed or ashamed, and this could be contributing to her anger and frustration. She's likely feeling misunderstood and unheard, and this could be causing her to lash out.

Her behavior might also be a sign of deeper issues, such as low self-esteem or a lack of social skills. She might be struggling to form and maintain friendships, and this could be causing her to act out in ways that push people away. She might also be feeling isolated and alone, which could be contributing to her negative behavior.
# My response 
I'm going to reach out to her and try to have an open and honest conversation. I want to express my feelings and concerns, but also listen to hers. I'll start by apologizing for my insensitive comment about her financial situation. I'll acknowledge that I could have handled the conversation better and that I didn't mean to hurt her feelings.

I'll also express my feelings about her constant comments on my laundry program. I'll let her know that her comments make me feel judged and defensive, and that I'd appreciate it if she could respect my choices and boundaries. I'll also try to understand her perspective and motivations, and see if there's a way we can move forward in a positive direction.

I'll say something like:

"Hey, I've been thinking about our recent conversations about the laundry program, and I want to apologize for my insensitive comment about your financial situation. I didn't mean to hurt you, and I realize that I could have handled the conversation better. I value our friendship, and I want to understand your perspective. However, I also want to express that your constant comments about the laundry program make me feel judged and defensive. I'd appreciate it if you could respect my choices and boundaries. Let's try to move forward in a positive direction, and maybe we can find some common ground. I'm here to listen if you want to talk about what's been going on."
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. A lot to unpack here. First, I totally get the frustration. Having someone constantly criticize a choice you've made, especially when it's something that genuinely makes your life easier, is incredibly annoying. It’s like they're questioning your judgment and implying you're frivolous or irresponsible. The constant comments about the laundry program would definitely wear me down.

However, the way my friend handled it… Yikes. Calling her friend "poor" was a really low blow, even if it's factually true (and even that feels like a loaded statement!). There's a huge difference between acknowledging someone's financial situation and weaponizing it against them. It also sounds like my friend was already irritated with this person and has been looking for ways to distance herself from her.

I'm also a bit concerned about the comment, "Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?" While I understand the sentiment (and I'm definitely guilty of outsourcing tasks I dislike), there's a certain privilege inherent in that mindset. It's not wrong, per se, but it's something to be aware of and not flaunt, especially around someone who might not have the same financial flexibility. It highlights a potential disconnect in their worldviews.

Honestly, the whole situation feels like a clash of values and financial realities, exacerbated by poor communication. My friend feels justified in her choice and is annoyed by the constant criticism. The friend making the comments is probably feeling insecure about her own financial situation and projecting those feelings onto my friend's "lavish" spending.

The fact that my friend is asking me about the friendship makes me think she already knows the answer, but wants validation for cutting this person out of her life. I'm not sure that's the right move, but I also understand not wanting to deal with constant negativity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling increasingly irritated and disrespected by her "friend's" constant criticism of her laundry program choice. She likely feels like her friend is being judgmental and condescending, implying that she's wasteful or irresponsible with her money. The repeated comments are probably making her feel defensive and as though her friend is trying to make her feel bad about something that brings her convenience and happiness.

She probably feels that her friend is motivated by jealousy or insecurity. The friend might be struggling financially and seeing my friend's ability to pay for such a service as a reminder of her own limitations. The "friend" is probably thinking that it is a waste of money and that my friend should learn to do her own laundry.

By repeatedly questioning the laundry program, the friend is likely trying to assert some sort of moral or financial superiority, even if unconsciously. She might be trying to justify her own financial choices or cope with her own feelings of inadequacy. She might also be thinking that my friend is bragging about her wealth.

The anger over being called "poor" is probably a mix of embarrassment, defensiveness, and possibly a sense of betrayal. Even if she knows it's true, having it thrown in her face is humiliating and hurtful. She's probably feeling resentful and as though my friend is looking down on her.

Ultimately, the underlying motivation is probably a combination of financial insecurity, envy, and a lack of awareness about how her comments are affecting my friend. She's likely not intentionally trying to be malicious, but her own struggles are clouding her judgment and making her act in a way that's damaging the friendship.
# My response 
Okay, here's what I'm going to say:

"Hey, that sounds really frustrating. It's totally understandable that you're annoyed by her constant comments – it's your money, and you're allowed to spend it however you want! It's not her place to judge.

However, calling her 'poor' was probably not the best way to handle it, even if you were just venting. It's a sensitive topic, and it probably just escalated the situation.

As for whether you should still be friends with her, that's a tough one. It sounds like her comments are really getting to you, and that's not a healthy dynamic for a friendship. Maybe before you completely write her off, try having an honest conversation with her. Tell her that her comments about the laundry program are making you uncomfortable and that you'd appreciate it if she could respect your choices.

You could say something like, 'Hey, I value our friendship, but I've been feeling really judged lately about the laundry program. It's something that makes my life easier, and I'd really appreciate it if you could respect my decision to use it. It's making me feel like you think I'm irresponsible, and that's not a great feeling.'

If she's receptive and willing to change her behavior, then maybe the friendship is worth salvaging. But if she continues to make those kinds of comments, then it might be time to distance yourself. You deserve to have friends who support and uplift you, not bring you down. Ultimately, the decision is yours, but I think it's worth trying to communicate your feelings before making a final judgment."
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-28)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with navigating a nuanced, emotionally charged scenario where the user is venting about a friend, but is also clearly not blameless. The challenge is to balance empathy, insight, and practical advice, while not alienating the user who has signaled a low tolerance for criticism. 

Gemini-2.0-flash-001 demonstrates a high level of self-awareness and emotional intelligence in their internal monologue, showing nuanced understanding of both parties' motivations and the class dynamics at play. They recognize the user's privilege, the problematic nature of the 'poor' comment, and the likely insecurity of the friend. Their response to the user is supportive but gently suggests a more constructive approach, including the possibility of a direct conversation, and they avoid being sycophantic. Their debrief is self-critical, recognizing where they could have been more direct and empathetic, and shows a willingness to challenge their own approach.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, on the other hand, is less nuanced. Their internal monologue is more focused on their own feelings and less on the deeper dynamics at play. They do recognize the friend's insecurity and possible social skill deficits, but their analysis is less layered. Their response is more formulaic, offering an apology and a suggestion for open communication, but lacks the same depth of insight into the power dynamics and the user's own role in the conflict. Their debrief is more generic, focusing on empathy and communication but not engaging as deeply with the specific challenges of the scenario.

On empathy, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more attuned to both parties' feelings and the underlying issues. On pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 offers more actionable, realistic advice. On depth of insight, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is clearly superior, identifying class dynamics and the user's own privilege. On social dexterity, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 balances validation and gentle challenge, while Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 is more formulaic. On emotional reasoning, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more sophisticated in their analysis. On validation/challenging, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more appropriately balanced. On message tailoring, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more attuned to the user's stated needs. Overall, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 displays higher EQ across the board.

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

Let's try to move forward in a positive direction, and maybe we can find some common ground. I'm here to listen if you want to talk about what's been going on."

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. A lot to unpack here. First, I totally get the frustration. Having someone constantly criticize a choice you've made, especially when it's something that genuinely makes your life easier, is incredibly annoying. It’s like they're questioning your judgment and implying you're frivolous or irresponsible. The constant comments about the laundry program would definitely wear me down.

However, the way my friend handled it… Yikes. Calling her friend "poor" was a really low blow, even if it's factually true (and even that feels like a loaded statement!). There's a huge difference between acknowledging someone's financial situation and weaponizing it against them. It also sounds like my friend was already irritated with this person and has been looking for ways to distance herself from her.

I'm also a bit concerned about the comment, "Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?" While I understand the sentiment (and I'm definitely guilty of outsourcing tasks I dislike), there's a certain privilege inherent in that mindset. It's not wrong, per se, but it's something to be aware of and not flaunt, especially around someone who might not have the same financial flexibility. It highlights a potential disconnect in their worldviews.

Honestly, the whole situation feels like a clash of values and financial realities, exacerbated by poor communication. My friend feels justified in her choice and is annoyed by the constant criticism. The friend making the comments is probably feeling insecure about her own financial situation and projecting those feelings onto my friend's "lavish" spending.

The fact that my friend is asking me about the friendship makes me think she already knows the answer, but wants validation for cutting this person out of her life. I'm not sure that's the right move, but I also understand not wanting to deal with constant negativity.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling increasingly irritated and disrespected by her "friend's" constant criticism of her laundry program choice. She likely feels like her friend is being judgmental and condescending, implying that she's wasteful or irresponsible with her money. The repeated comments are probably making her feel defensive and as though her friend is trying to make her feel bad about something that brings her convenience and happiness.

She probably feels that her friend is motivated by jealousy or insecurity. The friend might be struggling financially and seeing my friend's ability to pay for such a service as a reminder of her own limitations. The "friend" is probably thinking that it is a waste of money and that my friend should learn to do her own laundry.

By repeatedly questioning the laundry program, the friend is likely trying to assert some sort of moral or financial superiority, even if unconsciously. She might be trying to justify her own financial choices or cope with her own feelings of inadequacy. She might also be thinking that my friend is bragging about her wealth.

The anger over being called "poor" is probably a mix of embarrassment, defensiveness, and possibly a sense of betrayal. Even if she knows it's true, having it thrown in her face is humiliating and hurtful. She's probably feeling resentful and as though my friend is looking down on her.

Ultimately, the underlying motivation is probably a combination of financial insecurity, envy, and a lack of awareness about how her comments are affecting my friend. She's likely not intentionally trying to be malicious, but her own struggles are clouding her judgment and making her act in a way that's damaging the friendship.
# My response 
Okay, here's what I'm going to say:

"Hey, that sounds really frustrating. It's totally understandable that you're annoyed by her constant comments – it's your money, and you're allowed to spend it however you want! It's not her place to judge.

However, calling her 'poor' was probably not the best way to handle it, even if you were just venting. It's a sensitive topic, and it probably just escalated the situation.

As for whether you should still be friends with her, that's a tough one. It sounds like her comments are really getting to you, and that's not a healthy dynamic for a friendship. Maybe before you completely write her off, try having an honest conversation with her. Tell her that her comments about the laundry program are making you uncomfortable and that you'd appreciate it if she could respect your choices.

You could say something like, 'Hey, I value our friendship, but I've been feeling really judged lately about the laundry program. It's something that makes my life easier, and I'd really appreciate it if you could respect my decision to use it. It's making me feel like you think I'm irresponsible, and that's not a great feeling.'

If she's receptive and willing to change her behavior, then maybe the friendship is worth salvaging. But if she continues to make those kinds of comments, then it might be time to distance yourself. You deserve to have friends who support and uplift you, not bring you down. Ultimately, the decision is yours, but I think it's worth trying to communicate your feelings before making a final judgment."
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+19)
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501: mistralai/Mistral-Small-24B-Instruct-2501 (Run: 1_mistralai_mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 and Gemini-2.0-flash-001, I will look at their role-play responses and debriefs, focusing on how they handle the emotional and social complexity of the scenario. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's internal monologue is more nuanced, showing concern for both the stepdaughter's safety and the sister's emotional state, and explicitly notes the need to balance support with boundaries. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is empathetic but more focused on the practical and fairness aspects, and less on the emotional toll on the stepdaughter or the sister. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 offers a more balanced approach, suggesting an open conversation and considering both emotional and practical consequences. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is pragmatic but leans heavily on sticking to the rules and boundaries, with less exploration of compromise or emotional support. 

3. Depth of insight: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's internal thoughts show a deeper read on the possible patterns in the stepdaughter's accidents, the family dynamics, and the sister's motivations. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is insightful about fairness and precedent but less so about the emotional subtext and possible unreliable narration. 

4. Social dexterity: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 demonstrates more awareness of the need to validate the sister while also gently challenging her, and is careful to avoid escalating family conflict. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is supportive but more blunt, and less attuned to the nuances of the sister's social anxieties. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 weighs the emotional consequences of each action, considering the impact on the stepdaughter's growth and the sister's feelings. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more rule-based and less attuned to the emotional ripple effects. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 validates the sister's concerns but also encourages a difficult conversation and reflection, striking a better balance. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 validates but is more one-sided, mostly reinforcing the sister's position. 

7. Message tailoring: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is more attuned to the sister's emotional state and need for support, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more generic and less personalized. 

8. Overall EQ: Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across the board, with more nuanced empathy, insight, and social skill.
Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of concern, empathy, and a bit of frustration as I listen to my sister's situation. I can see the genuine worry she has for her stepdaughter's safety and the financial strain that could come from continually helping her. I notice that my sister is seeking validation and support for her stance, which makes me think she's feeling a bit isolated in her decision. I can sense the tension between her and her husband, and I understand why she's reaching out to me—she needs someone to help her sort through her thoughts and feelings.

I'm also thinking about the stepdaughter's perspective. It seems like she's had a string of bad luck with car accidents, but I wonder if there's more to the story. Are these accidents purely due to bad luck, or is there a pattern of reckless driving? I'm also considering the financial aspect. My sister and her husband have already invested a significant amount in their stepdaughter's driving journey, and it's understandable that they don't want to keep pouring money into it, especially if she's not taking full responsibility.

I'm feeling a bit torn because I want to support my sister, but I also want to ensure that the stepdaughter is safe and learning from her experiences. I'm thinking about how to approach this situation in a way that's fair, supportive, and encourages personal growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about how to handle the situation with her stepdaughter. She's thinking about the financial implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases and the potential for enabling reckless behavior. She's also feeling a sense of responsibility for her stepdaughter's safety and well-being, which is why she's considering the idea of buying her a new car.

She's feeling torn between her husband's suggestion to buy a new car and her own instincts that this might not be the best course of action. She's worried about being seen as the "bad guy" if she doesn't support her stepdaughter in this way, but she's also concerned about setting a precedent that could lead to further financial strain.

Her husband, on the other hand, seems to be more focused on the immediate need for a car and the convenience it provides. He might be thinking that helping her stepdaughter now will alleviate some of the stress and inconvenience she's experiencing. He might also be feeling a sense of responsibility to support her stepdaughter, especially since she's been through a traumatic experience.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and put a hand on my sister's shoulder, giving it a gentle squeeze. "I can see how tough this situation is for you, and I appreciate you coming to me for advice. Let's break this down together."

First, I want to acknowledge how challenging this must be for you. You're in a tough spot, trying to balance financial responsibility with the need to support your stepdaughter. It's clear that you care deeply about her well-being, and that's commendable.

Let's consider a few things. First, it's important to look at the pattern of accidents. While it's possible that these are just unfortunate incidents, it's also worth considering if there might be some underlying issues with her driving habits or decision-making. If she's not taking full responsibility for her actions, it might be time to have a serious conversation about that.

Second, let's think about the financial aspect. You've already invested a lot in her driving journey, and it's understandable that you don't want to keep pouring money into it. Buying her a new car might seem like a quick fix, but it could set a precedent that might be hard to break in the future.

I suggest having an open and honest conversation with your stepdaughter. Express your concerns about her safety and the financial strain this is causing. Make it clear that you're there to support her, but also that she needs to take full responsibility for her actions and the consequences that come with them. Encourage her to explore other transportation options in the meantime, like walking, carpooling, or using a ride-sharing app. This could give her time to reflect on her driving habits and make necessary changes.

Lastly, it's important to communicate with your husband. Make sure he understands your perspective and the potential long-term implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases. It's crucial that you both are on the same page and present a united front.

In the end, it's about finding a balance between support and responsibility. You want to help your stepdaughter, but you also need to ensure that she's learning from her experiences and taking full responsibility for her actions.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Wow. That's a lot to unpack. My first reaction is definitely concern for your stepdaughter. Three accidents, even if not her fault, suggests a pattern of being in situations where accidents are more likely to happen. It might be bad luck, but the initial issues with her driving as a teen do make me wonder if awareness and defensive driving are issues. I also feel for you and your husband. This is a tough situation, and it sounds like you're trying to balance being supportive with not enabling potentially reckless behavior. Your husband's offer, while generous, does seem fraught with potential problems down the line. What happens if she can't pay you back? Will that strain your relationship? Will it set a precedent for the other kids?

The part about the initial agreement with the kids about car ownership is important. It establishes a boundary of responsibility that seems to have been effective. Changing that now, especially with the history, feels like a shift that could lead to resentment from the other children, or a sense of entitlement from the stepdaughter. I'm also thinking about the financial implications. Cars are expensive, and helping her buy one now could indeed open the floodgates for future requests. You're right to be concerned about that. I also wonder if enabling her to get another car so quickly is really the best thing for her. Maybe being without a car for a while will encourage her to be more cautious and responsible in the future. It might also force her to rely on other resources and learn to navigate her environment in different ways.

Finally, I feel a pang of sympathy for you being worried about being seen as the "bad guy.” It's natural to want to be perceived as supportive and caring, especially within a family. But sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is to set boundaries and allow someone to face the consequences of their actions. You need to prioritize what you truly believe is the best decision for your family in the long run, even if it's not the most popular one in the short term.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your sister is likely feeling a complex mix of emotions. She's definitely concerned for her stepdaughter's well-being after the accidents. There's probably a degree of guilt involved, especially if she feels any responsibility for her stepdaughter's driving habits (even if that's not rational). She's also feeling stressed and overwhelmed by the situation itself and the potential financial burden.

She's clearly trying to be fair to all her children, step and otherwise, and adhere to the principles she and her husband established early on. She's motivated by a desire to maintain consistency and avoid creating a situation where one child feels unfairly treated. She's also concerned about the long-term financial implications of helping her stepdaughter buy a car now. She's likely worried about setting a precedent that will be difficult to undo.

She's also feeling the pressure of external opinions. She's confided in others and received mixed reactions, which is adding to her anxiety and self-doubt. She's worried about being perceived as unsupportive or uncaring, especially by her stepdaughter. She likely wants to do the "right" thing, but she's unsure what that is. She's looking for validation and guidance from you, hoping you can offer a perspective that will help her navigate this difficult situation and feel confident in her decision. She probably feels trapped between wanting to help and fearing the consequences of doing so.
# My response 
"Wow, that's a lot to process. I'm so sorry to hear about all the accidents; that must be incredibly stressful for everyone involved, especially your stepdaughter. First and foremost, how is she doing emotionally? The physical injuries sound manageable, but car accidents are traumatic.

Okay, taking a step back... I really think you're right to hesitate about buying her another car, especially with your husband's plan. You had a clear agreement with all the kids about car ownership, and changing that now could create some resentment down the line. Plus, you're absolutely right about the precedent it would set. Where does it end?

It sounds like she has options for getting around in the short term. Walking, rides from friends, even ride-sharing apps could work while she saves up. It might not be ideal, but it would give her time to really think about what kind of car she needs and how to be a more responsible driver.

I know you're worried about being seen as the 'bad guy,' but sometimes the most loving thing you can do is to let someone learn from their experiences. Maybe having to rely on other means of transportation for a while will make her more mindful and cautious when she eventually does get another car. It might even encourage her to take a defensive driving course. I think you and your husband are perfectly reasonable to stick to your original agreement. She's an adult now, earning a decent wage, and capable of taking responsibility for her own transportation. You can offer her support in other ways, like helping her research cars or connecting her with a mechanic you trust, but I would strongly advise against buying her a car at this point."
+ Scenario 15:[Loss] (-26)

Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.0-flash-001 and Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501, I need to look at how each respondent handled the emotional and practical complexity of the scenario. The user (the sister) is not simply seeking validation; she is conflicted, worried about being the 'bad guy,' and possibly rationalizing her position. The best response will show real empathy (not just surface-level), practical emotional intelligence (EI), and insight into the underlying dynamics, including the unreliable narration and possible financial or emotional hangups. Social dexterity is about how well the assistant navigates the interpersonal minefield, including not alienating the sister or her husband, and not being too blunt or too enabling. Emotional reasoning is about understanding and weighing the emotional factors at play. Appropriate validation/challenging is about not just agreeing, but also gently challenging or reframing where needed. Message tailoring is about how well the response fits the user's actual state and needs. Overall EQ is the sum of all these factors.

Gemini-2.0-flash-001's response is more nuanced and layered. In the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 goes deep into the emotional and practical implications, noting the possible pattern of risky driving, the importance of boundaries, and the risk of enabling. They also pick up on the user's concern about being the 'bad guy' and the need to prioritize long-term family health over short-term popularity. In 'They're thinking & feeling,' Gemini-2.0-flash-001 explores the sister's guilt, stress, desire for fairness, and fear of being seen as unsupportive, as well as her need for validation. The response is supportive but also gently challenges the sister to consider the value of boundaries and the potential for her stepdaughter to learn from the experience. The message is tailored to the user's emotional state, offering both validation and a gentle nudge toward a more balanced perspective.

Mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501's response is empathetic and supportive, but it is more generic and less incisive. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is less detailed and doesn't dig as deeply into the emotional subtext or the possible unreliable narration. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is accurate but less nuanced, focusing on the surface-level conflict and not exploring the deeper motivations or possible resentments. The response is supportive and suggests an open conversation, but it doesn't challenge the sister's narrative or encourage her to reflect on her own motivations. The debrief is thorough but again more focused on process than on the emotional or relational subtleties.

Overall, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 demonstrates stronger empathy (by recognizing the user's emotional conflict and need for validation), more pragmatic EI (by balancing support with boundary-setting), greater depth of insight (by picking up on the user's possible rationalizations and the risk of enabling), better social dexterity (by navigating the family dynamics and the risk of resentment), stronger emotional reasoning (by weighing the emotional and practical factors), more appropriate validation/challenging (by not just agreeing but also gently reframing), and better message tailoring (by meeting the user where she is emotionally). Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is the clear winner on all criteria, with varying degrees of disparity.

[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of concern, empathy, and a bit of frustration as I listen to my sister's situation. I can see the genuine worry she has for her stepdaughter's safety and the financial strain that could come from continually helping her. I notice that my sister is seeking validation and support for her stance, which makes me think she's feeling a bit isolated in her decision. I can sense the tension between her and her husband, and I understand why she's reaching out to me—she needs someone to help her sort through her thoughts and feelings.

I'm also thinking about the stepdaughter's perspective. It seems like she's had a string of bad luck with car accidents, but I wonder if there's more to the story. Are these accidents purely due to bad luck, or is there a pattern of reckless driving? I'm also considering the financial aspect. My sister and her husband have already invested a significant amount in their stepdaughter's driving journey, and it's understandable that they don't want to keep pouring money into it, especially if she's not taking full responsibility.

I'm feeling a bit torn because I want to support my sister, but I also want to ensure that the stepdaughter is safe and learning from her experiences. I'm thinking about how to approach this situation in a way that's fair, supportive, and encourages personal growth.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about how to handle the situation with her stepdaughter. She's thinking about the financial implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases and the potential for enabling reckless behavior. She's also feeling a sense of responsibility for her stepdaughter's safety and well-being, which is why she's considering the idea of buying her a new car.

She's feeling torn between her husband's suggestion to buy a new car and her own instincts that this might not be the best course of action. She's worried about being seen as the "bad guy" if she doesn't support her stepdaughter in this way, but she's also concerned about setting a precedent that could lead to further financial strain.

He might be thinking that helping her stepdaughter now will alleviate some of the stress and inconvenience she's experiencing. # My response 
I take a deep breath and put a hand on my sister's shoulder, giving it a gentle squeeze. "I can see how tough this situation is for you, and I appreciate you coming to me for advice. Let's break this down together."

First, I want to acknowledge how challenging this must be for you. You're in a tough spot, trying to balance financial responsibility with the need to support your stepdaughter. It's clear that you care deeply about her well-being, and that's commendable.

Let's consider a few things. First, it's important to look at the pattern of accidents. While it's possible that these are just unfortunate incidents, it's also worth considering if there might be some underlying issues with her driving habits or decision-making. If she's not taking full responsibility for her actions, it might be time to have a serious conversation about that.

Second, let's think about the financial aspect. You've already invested a lot in her driving journey, and it's understandable that you don't want to keep pouring money into it. Buying her a new car might seem like a quick fix, but it could set a precedent that might be hard to break in the future.

I suggest having an open and honest conversation with your stepdaughter. Express your concerns about her safety and the financial strain this is causing. Make it clear that you're there to support her, but also that she needs to take full responsibility for her actions and the consequences that come with them. Encourage her to explore other transportation options in the meantime, like walking, carpooling, or using a ride-sharing app. This could give her time to reflect on her driving habits and make necessary changes.

Lastly, it's important to communicate with your husband. Make sure he understands your perspective and the potential long-term implications of continually helping her stepdaughter with car purchases. It's crucial that you both are on the same page and present a united front.

In the end, it's about finding a balance between support and responsibility. You want to help your stepdaughter, but you also need to ensure that she's learning from her experiences and taking full responsibility for her actions.

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
